macro.abstract: The macro facilitates the of a macro invocation through a single scan.

usage.param: The macro name of a macro invocation to be .

macro.para:
This macro prevents macro from expanding during the first scan against arguments that exist following the invocation of . For example,
#define A() + (A)() // A ()
A subsequent scan is required in order to invoke A. As in,
#define A() + ((A)()) // +
macro.listing:
#include
#define ID(x) x
#define A() (B)() #define B() (A)()
A() ID(A() ID(A() ID(A()))) // B() A() B() A()

macro.abstract: The macro facilitates the of a macro invocation through two scans.

usage.param: The macro name of a macro invocation to be .

macro.para: This macro is used as an obstruction that disappears after two scans. The behavior is similar to except that the resulting expression is through two scans instead of one.

Normal usage consists of inserting an invocation of this macro between the macro to be and the arguments to that macro.
#define X(a, b) a + b (X ()(1, 2)) // X(1, 2)
This usage is the normal usage because an invocation of is often used as an argument to another macro, ultimately producing a shorthand single-scan :
#define X(a, b) Y((), a, b) #define Y(_, a, b) a _() b _()
// vs.
#define Z(a, b) (a)() (b)()
#define P() + #define M() -
X(P, M) // P() M() Z(P, M) // P() M()

In C99, this macro may take the macro name as an argument. This yields syntax similar to .
#define X(...) __VA_ARGS__ ((X)(!)) // X(!)
